name: Alishia Williams
description: 12 min lectures?? Sounds good in theory, but probably a challenge to cover all content traditionally covered in a semester. But that raises the question of whether we try to cram in too much information.

name: Alishia Williams
description: I'm pro technological aids - but from experience know that when we become too reliant upon them and the technology fails (video recording, link to upload etc) chaos can result.

name: Christy Newman
description: I'm most convinced by the argument that many students will learn the content of a lecture better (and deeper) if they have the option to start and stop a lecture recording as required, rather than having to try to keep up while sitting in a lecture theatre!

name: Christy Newman
description: I like the idea of starting each lecture with an open quiz to get people engaged and ready for the session!

name: Christy Newman
description: As a lecturer in a big course, who doesn't run any tutorials myself, I'm very much attracted to the option of getting more direct connections with a greater number of students, through the flipped classroom model.

name: Christy Newman
description: Great ideas about how to share responses - by identifying those groups most likely to be most interesting/different and actively asking them to share, you avoid the issue of students being unwilling to share their ideas in case they look silly.

name: Christy Newman
description: Amazing to think of all the possibilities afforded by recording group activities in lecture sessions, so students can access them later!

name: Christy Newman
description: I've heard a little about flipped classrooms before, but this video has given me lots of concrete ideas about what is possible through this approach, I really like it! It's a bit daunting to think about the work required to set it up, recording the (short) videos beforehand, for example, but the benefits for student learning are clear, and I think the students I teach would really love it. Lots of things for me to think about now in terms of restructuring my course for next year...

name: Lincoln Gomes
description: It's interesting to hear that the traditional lecture was cut down from 50 mins to 12-15 mins. What content was cut out? Was this content used during the flipped classroom time?

name: Lincoln Gomes
description: It's interesting to see that although the flipped classroom is being used, the room itself is not equipped to handle the group work. What sort of things can lecturers do to make the most of the current spaces provided for giving lectures?

name: Lincoln Gomes
description: I like the idea of getting students to contribute their ideas to the rest of the cohort, but what about considerations for students who would like to contribute but are not necessarily comfortable being filmed? It makes me think of what I could do to get the quieter ones more involved in class discussion, whilst not making them feel like they are being isolated for being quiet.

name: Lincoln Gomes
description: The flipped classroom is certainly more dynamic. Having been a student in one course that employs it, it does force you to think much more critically about the content. I would still like to know about more ways to include quieter students in discussion without making them feel isolated. ie. how can the flipped classroom be made more inclusive rather than just providing an outlet for the most vocal students?

name: Lucas Lixinski
description: Right off the bat, I am not sure how relevant this is to my current teaching practice, as I only teach small groups (usually around 20-30 students, at any rate capped at 44). But I've taught big lectures in the past, so, we'll see.

name: Lucas Lixinski
description: Yes, the lecture time is cut down, but I would think part of the "efficiency" is because there is no time for discussions anymore.And maybe it's a lack of student conditioning for this model, but, in my flipped classroom experience, students who do not understand a concept in the video are unlikely to make a note of the question and bring it to class for discussion.I don't know, I think I'm too much of a control freak to assume that any questions a student might have will resolve themselves inside the small group, during the activity.

name: Lucas Lixinski
description: I like the idea of adding a timer to the screen, I don't know why I hadn't done that before.

name: Lucas Lixinski
description: So, what is the rest of the class supposed to do while the few students are recording their videos? I missed that step.

name: Lucas Lixinski
description: It's certainly an interesting approach to flipped classrooms. We have been experimenting with some of that at the Law Faculty, and I've been involved in some flipped classroom course design. We do things a bit differently, because our groups are quite a bit smaller, but I can see a lot of similarities, too.One thing that particularly struck me about the video is the notion that all student questions can be answered if the student is able to slow down and rewind the video. From my experience, very often the information just needs to be conveyed in a different way, and, while the classroom might be an opportunity to do just that, the video didn't seem to convey there would be much space for group discussion of issues raised in the videos, just individual consultations at the end of class.

name: Apo Demirkol
description: It is a good idea that they actually do some work beforhand that would go with they are to do in the classroom

name: Apo Demirkol
description: I always thought that optimizing the pace of my talks was the most difficult task when delivering a lecture! I like the idea that the talks are reproducible!

name: Apo Demirkol
description: this is infact more work than usual delivery of a lecture but it is less likely to have dead-fish faces in this type of teaching in the classroom!

name: Apo Demirkol
description: i think it is plausible that they can develop more instructive relationships with their instructor

name: Apo Demirkol
description: I think this could be viable in my teaching but I am aware of the fact that it is a lot of work! For a conjoint, it is a daunting thought!

name: Paul Munro
description: It sounds good in theory. But there are some issues. First, organising 200+ students into groups each lecture is a pretty big logistical challenge for just one lecturer. A lot of time can be lost just getting things arrange. Second, some classroom (lecture theatre) layouts aren't that conducive for group work (i.e., they have been designed for lecture formats); and third,we need to take into account how this approach might affect SEADU students

name: Paul Munro
description: It would be interesting to see student feedback to gather their perspective on the approach. Also, I wonder if this approach is more conducive from some disciplines more than others.

name: Paul Munro
description: It seems like a really interesting approach, and I would like to experiment with it (perhaps try it out for one or two weeks next semester) before implementing it in full. I am wondering about tutorials? How do they link into this approach?

name: Jesse Cale
description: That's an interesting concept using vidoes- It seems similar to what I have done in the past such as asking students to read a paper or watch a documentary before coming to a seminar or tutorial...only works when they actually do it though!!

name: Jesse Cale
description: Ok- that's a good idea to ensure student's have actually watched the lecture. very interesting, I have never heard of this before!

name: Jesse Cale
description: I'm actually really impressed by this. It's a really innovative strategy. I would be very interested to learn much more about this. I suppose there must be different in class activities that could be implemented. I would definitely like to explore what these would be.

name: Jesse Cale
description: I guess one of my questions would be how feasible it is to make students complete a quiz each class. While I am all for this, in my experience at least here, I think the students would revolt! On the other hand, making each worth minimal marks might not be enough to ensure they all participate consistently which would then create some problems with the group work.

name: Jesse Cale
description: I'm actually really impressed by this. It's a really innovative strategy. I would be very interested to learn much more about this. I suppose there must be different in class activities that could be implemented. I would definitely like to explore what these would be.

name: Jesse Cale
description: I guess one of my questions would be how feasible it is to make students complete a quiz each class. While I am all for this, in my experience at least here, I think the students would revolt! On the other hand, making each worth minimal marks might not be enough to ensure they all participate consistently which would then create some problems with the group work.

name: Leonie Ligertwood
description: I'd previously thought that a traditional lecture theatre would be antithetical to the implementation of the flipped classroom.  I was most impressed - he managed the learning process simply and effectively.

name: Sue Williamson
description: I like the idea of students watching a video and then doing group exercises in class. I could use this, as some of my material is quite dry. I've also made the videos, so am ready to go!

name: Sue Williamson
description: This approach is very interesting. My students have commented that some of the material in my course is a little dry, so this would certainly help to make it more interesting. I've already done the videos too, which would help me. But then, I wonder about tutorials - how would tutorial activities be different?

name: Dianne Anagnos
description: A huge improvement to the lecture-style approach for large groups.  However it also seems quite resource- intensive for the teacher.  I teach much smaller groups where there is time for small-group work and for all students to present their work to the larger group and ask questions along the way, but this may still be worth exloring.

name: Mark Braidwood
description: The lecture room looks unsuitable to group work

name: Mark Braidwood
description: Do lecturers get training on how to lecture to a video camera? Seems like a good idea

name: Mark Braidwood
description: What about introverts? Does this model apply better to extroverts?

name: Jeff Coulton
description: The business school has constructed a number of 'flipped classrooms'. Good to see that the 'traditional' space can be used in a flipped manner.

name: Jeff Coulton
description: Neat use of common technology to capture group outcomes

name: Jeff Coulton
description: I've used the clock in exams, but it's a neat idea for groupwork as well

name: Jeff Coulton
description: Some good examples of using a traditional space in a flipped way - ie we don't have to rely on specifically redesigned teaching spaces. Like the use of the phone camera and countdown.

name: Thomas McConochie
description: This is the first flipped classroom I have seen in the form of a lecture. It looks like the lecture has become a large tutorial session. If that is the case, then what is the point of having "lectures"?

name: Julie Wilson
description: I can see a real benefit to student learning  through the flipped classroom model. The current course I teach does not upload the Lectures for obvious reasons however, the ability of students to stop rewind and go over content definitely can enhance student learning.

name: Julie Wilson
description: Creating the space for more one on one time with the students to see learning in action and to answer questions is certainly valuable for student engagement and deep learning.

name: Julie Wilson
description: I like the interactive nature of the flipped classroom Model and the ability of the teacher to  spend more one on one time with students. I would be interested in student feedback and how different personalities felt participating.

name: Josh Wodak
description: An interesting overview of flipped classroom but doesn't seem to be a good example of a type of physical classroom to 'flip' ie the steep tiered seating, inability to change seating direction and size of room don't seem conducive to forming groups for more interactive and participatory student engagement. Although, given most lecture theatures have this physical structure and its inherent limitations, maybe they used this example because it represents that type of rooms that flipped teaching is trying to take place within.

name: Ginu Rajan
description: Normally in standard class room teaching, students just turn-up without any idea of what being in the lecture. But in flipped classroom approach, it is necessary that the students should watch the video before the class. So the question is how effective is this?, and how practical it is. In my opinion at least 50% might turn up without watching. In such a scenario, how can we make the teaching effective

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
description: Students are asked to watch a lecture online before coming to class- I wonder how common Flipped classroom is at UNSW and how happy/resistant students would be to putting in a fair amount of time both before and after class?

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
tags: Students group up into small groups
description: This sounds like a very large tutorial. What is the role of the tutorial then and what gets covered/what activities?

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
description: The lecture is cut down significantly (around 1/4 - 1/2 of what it would normally take)- I find this fascinating- what are we spending half the lecture doing ? Does he just go through the material faster because he knows students can re-watch parts that they find confusing? I think that even though the lecture content is cut down, most (conscientious) students will still need to spend a full hour going back and forth through the material.

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
tags: students can slow down or re-watch the video
description: I think this is great, that the lecture is recorded and available so that students can view it as many times as they need to.

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
tags: Students complete an open note quiz
description: I think this would be very useful and that you would probably have to use a quiz to ensure that students do the online work before coming to class. From what I know about Flipped Classroom, sometimes the quiz is given online before the class-time so that the teacher can see what topics students are struggling with, and address these in the Face to Face.

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
description: I wonder what the group size is? I agree with Lincoln-it doesn't look very easy for the groups to come together in the traditional lecture theatre design.

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
description: I like how student's work is recorded both by still shots and video- I can imagine this would be very useful for students when studying for final exams.

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
tags: students can ask questions at the end
description: I wonder if this approach would encourage the shy students to ask questions?

name: Sacha Stelzer-Braid
description: I find this approach really exciting- flipped classroom changes the role of the lecturer from one who presents the material, to one who presents the material beforehand and then moderates the flow of ideas and discussion in a workshop type environment. I wonder how common flipped classroom is at UNSW and how happy/resistant students would be to putting in a fair amount of time both before and after class? For the lecturer this involves alot more work, but ultimately the results would be worth it, as you are teaching your students to think critically and analyse the information you give them. I would really like to try this in one lecture coming up.

name: Peyman Mostaghimi Qomi
description: To me the flipped classroom seems an excellent idea. However, I think it will need some sort of modifications based on the course content. For some courses, students will need specific resources to be able to complete their learning in the classroom. I would like to know if this scheme has ever been tried at UNSW and what was the experience of the lecturer.

name: Mark Reed
description: this is an interesting model - I can see how it works when all students spend time prior to the class - my experience is that students not so prepared - then the experience would be very bad and they would be totally lost in the class

name: Mark Reed
description: interesting model - it relies on students doing prep - most don't

name: Yun Hau Ng
description: The idea is interesting. Would it be more or less similar with ECHO360 implemented in CATS lecture room? Students can listen to the recorded lectures and do revision as many times as they like with their own preferred pace. The only difference is in flipped classroom the students are supposed to watch (or learn?) it before they attend the lecture. Same things could be done by loading the previously recorded (say last year)ECHO360 lecture before each class.

name: Yun Hau Ng
description: Would that be more tutorial-type instead of lecture? I guess the main challenge for my course would be how to make sure the students done the study before they attend to the class, especially when the class size is large. If the students come without prior studying (not just watching) the topic, the whole lecture would be just ineffective at all??!!

name: Yun Hau Ng
description: Do we need to get the students consent before recording them? I reckon not everyone is happy to be filmed and put on publicly accessed medium.

name: Yun Hau Ng
description: This is an interesting model.I guess the main challenge for my course would be how to make sure the students done the study (not just watching the video) before they attend the class. If the students come without prior study, does that mean the whole lecture would be meaningless for them at all, as the activities designed are for those prepared ones?

name: Tom Kramer
description: I love the idea of smaller classes cut down from 200 plus pax.

name: Tom Kramer
description: Ahhh...but will students be disciplined enough to do the pre-wprk...doubtful.

name: Tom Kramer
description: Wonderful that students can go throug hthe material at their own pace so long as the original delivery is clear and coherent.

name: Tom Kramer
description: The classes are fun and engaging..new methods are always interesting and usually inspirational.

name: Ronald Ting Tai Chan
description: The concept is basically to ask the students and lecturer to switch role during lecture time.

name: Tom Kramer
description: I love the idea that the information dump and delivery is short and sharp. I think the use of reviewable video is especially fantastic as English challenged students can go at their own pace...BUT will students do the preliminary work for the class??!!??

name: Ronald Ting Tai Chan
description: I'm not so sure that this is a definite way to 'save time'. I agree that in a class size of 30-60. Breaking up students into groups help to encourage thinking and the lecturer to provide individual support. However, in a class of 200, it would be almost impossible to provide assistance to all the groups in a time-efficient manner.

name: Ronald Ting Tai Chan
tags: Students can do it at their own pace
description: This part I agree. This is especially important as many students are not naive English speakers. Giving them the ability to playback the lecture at any time will definitely help them to learn. One drawback would be the lecturer has to be very careful of what has being recorded especially if confidential information is involved e.g. performance discussion of Coca Cola.

name: Vidhyasaharan Sethu
description: I wonder if there are scenarios where making students watch a recorded lecture prior to class is not advisable/optimal? - Perhaps a lecture that involves very complex mathematics, or one that can be augmented with a live experiment/demonstration?

name: Vidhyasaharan Sethu
description: I'm not sure if it will be possible to make sure students watch the videos before attending the lecture - even with a quiz they may not care to do so. What options are available in this case? Or is this situation no different from students not paying attention in a regular class?

name: Vidhyasaharan Sethu
description: Is this workable without the use of groups? How to deal with the issue of some group members not coming prepared, and not participating while others carry the group activities?

name: Vidhyasaharan Sethu
description: I have taught laboratory based courses in  a flipped mode but I'm very interested in how to make them work for more theory based courses. Some of the ideas presented are interesting but the ideas presented are for a specific course and will have be modified (perhaps quite a lot) to fit other courses. Some issue that I see others have also raised which bother me are: (1) What to do with students who don't watch the videos prior to class, even with the quiz; (2) What if activities suitable for the course cannot result in something that expressed briefly?; (3) Are there alternatives to group activities that can ensure students are engaged?; (4) Are there courses/types of courses where pre-recorded videos are sub-optimal?

name: Hongxu Lu
description: This point is very important. The students can control their learning progress. Especially when they didn't catch the words, they have chances to learn it again.

name: Hongxu Lu
description: It's very insteresting to watch this impresive video. I personally think the flipped Classroom provides a lot of benefits to the students however gives some challenges to the teachers.

name: Forrest Duxbury
description: I like this technique of real quizzes in the lecture. Firstly doesn't let students disengage from the droning of a lecturer, secondly encourages them to engage deep thinking to solve the quiz so that they are capable of conversing intelligently in groups with their colleagues.

name: Forrest Duxbury
description: This is really nice. I can see the students needing to be prepared ahead of time, it has the capacity to fail easily if under prepared, but otherwise it brings real engagement and reflection to each lecture.

name: Forrest Duxbury
description: Not knowing who is going to be called up keeps students engaged. Asking questions of audience keeps students on their toes. Recording it allows students to reflect for study purposes or if they missed the class. Friendships are encouraged due to the experiences, allowing better social engagement as well. All positive techniques when organised properly.

name: Jing Zhao
description: I guess most of us assign required readings to students before class, yet my experience is not all students would do it. This means we need to think harder about setting up some follow-up or perhaps even hurdles so that students feel they have to do it.

name: Jing Zhao
description: The scenario would be very different depending on class size.

name: Forrest Duxbury
description: I see all the techniques demonstrated in this example as extremely valuable to teaching staff and students. Engagement, social interaction and reflection all are vastly improved by this model.This experience is something that can be replicated at UNSW within the Blackboard Collaborate webinar software. They have groups / breakout rooms / video + audio sharing / timers / student group detailed whiteboards that can be shared with all in the main room / polls and are recorded for later review.I was in a flipped classroom style course once before, and found there was a lot of doubt from the students to the efficacy of what we were doing. The teacher was brilliant and much respected, but doubts came in, possibly because he didn't sell or explain the model strongly enough to the students. We all valued it over all, but definitely something to prepare for ahead of time.

name: Jing Zhao
description: Felxibility in learning pace and context will appeal to students.

name: Jing Zhao
description: Felxibility in learning pace and context will certainly appeal to students. Yet, I guess most of us assign required readings to students before class, while all students do it. This means we need to think harder about setting up some follow-up or perhaps even hurdles so that students feel they have to do it.Further, the scenarios would be very different depending on class size.

name: Robert Walsh
description: I assume in cutting the lecturing time down so dramatically he is presenting only a brief summary of what was covered in the prep. videos. Sounds like a good chance for the students to refresh their memory of the content and check that they have included the main points in their notes - but only works if they have done the work...

name: Robert Walsh
description: Like the idea of hitting pause on a lecture - especially given the pace he talks!

name: Robert Walsh
description: Can see great value in attacking subject matter from several angles is is happening here. The lecture room environment looks particularly cumbersome for group work however so I'd be looking for a better format for that.

name: Nayana Bibile
description: I am not completely convinced with the actual time saving in the delivery of the lecture. However, great for self-paced learning. The charisma of giving a lecture and conveying the idea of the subject in person can be lost.

name: Nayana Bibile
description: This can be a very active process for everyone, especially getting the students to engage with their own classmates.

name: Nayana Bibile
description: Enhanced critical review through the video material is very useful.

name: Nayana Bibile
description: It has quite a lot of positive processes. 1) self-paced learning; 2) critical reflection can be enhanced; 3) classmates are motivated to engage with each other. However, see some challenges, especially the loss of that charisma of the lecture.

name: Robert Walsh
description: The idea of engaging in active learning modes during the lecture over blindly copying down notes is very appealing. Key factors to consider:-providing the necessary motivation for students to do the prep. work.-providing motivation to turn up to the lectures given content is available on-line.-suitability of environment for group based activities.-effect on the more introverted students?

name: Laura Crommelin
description: So this looks like a really effective strategy for making large-format classes more engaging, but I wonder about whether there's as much to gain in the kind of small-format teaching I do.  I also feel like it's a bit of a redistribution of tasks - if students are watching lectures outside of class time, that presumably means less time for external readings.  But the classes themselves look really engaged and much more effective than the large-format classes I remember attending in my degrees, so it definitely seems worth investigating! Plus while filming the lectures would take time, it would really pay off for courses offered every semester or with multiple streams.

name: Niki Fardouly
description: Is he recording the entire lecture or key concepts in short chunks? It can be really hard to concentrate for a full hour or more on a talking head.

name: Niki Fardouly
description: The lecture theatre setup doesn't help with conducting group project discussions.

name: Niki Fardouly
description: Good to hear that they aren't recording an entire hour. Answers my previous comment.

name: Niki Fardouly
description: This quiz sounds like a tracking exercise to see if they did their pre-class work. I'm surprised they aren't asked to do this before coming to class. Why does it need to be done in class time?

name: Niki Fardouly
description: Mini whiteboards? That's a novel low-tech idea! I wonder why they aren't using mobile devices and recording directly online? This seems like a laborious process for the lecturer to get the student responses online.

name: Niki Fardouly
description: The recording of the best student responses on video must be a great incentive for the students to do the task well.

name: Niki Fardouly
description: Great outcomes! 1. Students publish their own critical and creative thought products.2. Able to reflect later by going back to watch the videos and watch themselves perform, so improving their performance skills.3. Able to develop more high quality relationships with their instructor.

name: Niki Fardouly
description: I can see lots of benefits in getting the students to view lecture recordings as pre-work and using class time for this sort of interactive and collaborative learning. It must be very motivating for the students to come prepared to class and to be fully engaged in the classroom activities. I wonder how much they benefit if they haven't watched the videos?

name: Zhe An
description: I think it is really depend on the course you teach.Some course, such as commerce is easy to do so.However, it will be much harder to do it in a maths course.

name: Zhe An
description: I like the flipped classroom idea which allows students engage and participate in class. Flexibility in teaching and learning provide a great platform to students to learn and apply knowledge.

name: Dianne Anagnos
description: I am still struggling to work out how I might use this format in my classes.  I teach smaller groups of 15-30 in a fairly participative format.  The students ask questions throughout the class, we do lots of brainstorming activities as a group and a lot of group-work and project-work. Obviously a pre-recorded lecture would give us more time during class to undertake more work.  But I don't like that "question-time" happens at the end of the class in this format.  I like the fact that the students' oral presentation skills are constantly being developed in this model.

name: Juan Pablo Escobedo-Diaz
description: I like the idea of cutting on lecture time.

name: Juan Pablo Escobedo-Diaz
description: I wonder how many students actually watch the video before coming to class.

name: Juan Pablo Escobedo-Diaz
description: Yes there is a lot of appeal in this approach. However my main concern/curiosity would be how this will be effectively applied to the math-based (engineering) classes.

name: Siranda Torvaldsen
description: The part that really resonated with me was the bit about during a lecture, some students will be struggling to keep up, whilst for others it will be too slow. Many of the students I teach come from very different academic backgrounds, so for some the information I am imparting is all new (and for those students I probably gloss over it too quickly), whilst for others it is very basic and just revision.

name: Siranda Torvaldsen
description: As a result of my readings and watching this video, I have become convinced that this flipped classroom approach is a far superior teaching method than the traditional lecture. It is a more efficient use of face-to-face time.

name: Patricia Arthur
description: Good to get an actual definition of what is a flipped calssroom!

name: Patricia Arthur
description: Good for student pacing themselves.

name: Patricia Arthur
description: Sharing responses - great for sharing ideas

name: Patricia Arthur
description: Loving this! I would like more informaiton on the 'quiz' idea at the start of the lecture. Also, the place, then , of the traditional 'tutorial' in this mode of delivery? I see in some courses in my school that 'flippng' has been used to seliver content, but that's abut all.

name: Md. Hossain
description: Although we are shaving some time by cutting the lecture length, still we spending more time on preparing the video!

name: Md. Hossain
description: Idea is quite interesting, but, whats about if the students doesn't understood properly from the video. There should have some time to solve the problems.

name: Md. Hossain
description: This part is quite interesting, getting response from student group.

name: Md. Hossain
description: The idea is quite interesting and it will certainly help students to understand the topic before coming to the actual class. I guess, it would be more helpful for the students if we collect the feedback from students while they are watching video. In this way we will be able to know which part of lecture are not clear to the students and make those clear at the very beginning of class. Then, we can move to the quiz part.

name: Fatima Afzal
description: its interesting to note that we are some how flipping the classroom already without knowing the term. It has some great benefits  but the main barrier in flipping is the assurance that the students actually read/watch the material before coming to the class.

name: Meng Tok
description: I like the idea of the flipped classroom but I think it will be more effective in lecture based teaching environment than small group tutorial which already tend to be more interactive. For example, students are often able to ask questions and clarify their understanding during tutorial. Another limitation that I can see is that students need to have watch the boring factual/content based video prior to coming to class to be able to participate in the discussions/activities. However the clear advantages from the flipped classroom are: Reducing the time to present content through pre lecture video recordings. Allowing students to watch the lecture as many times as they need to understand the key points/content. Having time for feedback, quizzes and/or questions during the face to face session.

name: Stephen Doherty
description: I think the term is new but the idea is long established, it's an excellent way to help students get the most out of face-to-face time for their courses.

name: Stephen Doherty
description: The room organisation seems a bit awkward here. I'd feel more comfortable starting out the 'fipped' content on a small group as it's be easier to gauage their reception and progress with the material. I'd fear that in a large lecture, some students wouldn't view/read the materials at home and miss out without being picked up by the lecturer.

name: Stephen Doherty
description: What about students who don't watch the video and 'hide' in their groups while the rest do the work? (I'm being cynical, but it happens!)

name: Stephen Doherty
description: Are all of the other students *really* paying attention while the facilitator interviews one student at the front with the video?

name: Stephen Doherty
description: What sort of workload can we expect from the pre- and post-class tasks involved in this extensive flipping? Currently, I have 3 hours allocated to 1 lecture hour, is this doable?
